image.altText: A red billboard featuring images of Shane King MP and Mark Ryan MP.

props.synopsis: Ahead of this month's state election, several MPs from both Labor and the LNP have used their electorate and communication allowances to pay for billboards spruiking themselves.

title.children: Queensland MPs use taxpayer-funded allowances to pay for billboards of themselves

image.altText: a woman smiling on a beach

props.synopsis: A new study investigating the link between sleep and pain could fundamentally change the way doctors and clinicians treat people with chronic pain.

title.children: New sleep study could be 'game-changer' for millions of Australians suffering from chronic pain

image.altText: A firefighter stand by a tanker as bush burns in the distance below an orange sky.

props.synopsis: As large parts of Queensland brace for bushfire season, a state government review has been told woefully inadequate phone service in some regional areas poses a "direct threat to public safety".

title.children: Poor phone service and confusing warnings put lives at risk during fires, floods and cyclones, review finds

image.altText: Shot of Steven Miles smiling as a mobile phone films him in the foreground.

props.synopsis: Labor is vying for a fourth term in government but is facing a tough battle from the LNP, particularly in regional Queensland.

title.children: Premier Steven Miles leaves door open for minority government as Queensland election campaign kicks off

image.altText: A serious man and a woman stand in field of crops, man, wears cap, looks down, woman looks away, blue sky, trees.

props.synopsis: Fiona and Rob Duff say rejecting the potential cash flow from wind turbines is not an ideological decision about climate change or energy.

title.children: Couple turns down wind turbines worth millions due to decommissioning concerns

image.altText: A skyline of units in Townsville.

props.synopsis: Once known for its affordable housing, the garrison city of Townsville is seeing property prices soar, as buyers report hot competition.

title.children: Townsville house prices growing faster than all Australian capital cities

image.altText: A tall man leaves a room... it says townsville council meeting

props.synopsis: In his final act as Queensland premier before parliament is dissolved, Steven Miles has moved to axe Troy Thompson as Townsville mayor for 12 months amid a Crime and Corruption Commission investigation.

title.children: Queensland premier moves to oust embattled Townsville mayor for misleading voters

image.altText: Man holding hand in hospital bed.

props.synopsis: Austin Ballard was charged with unlawful striking causing death after a 22-year-old suffered a severe head injury during an alleged brawl between three groups of young men at Burleigh Heads.

title.children: Teen accused of fatal assault during Gold Coast brawl released on bail

image.altText: Brisbane voter at polling place

props.synopsis: Do you have to vote in a state election? And can you cast your ballot in a different electorate? We have your questions covered.

title.children: The corflutes are out and letterbox drops are underway. Here's how and when to vote in the Queensland election

image.altText: Traffic driving along street at a new housing estate.

props.synopsis: News that Treasury was looking at modelling changes to negative gearing was treated as a scandal. But when it comes to Australia's housing affordability problem, wouldn't the real scandal be if Treasury officials WEREN'T examining every possible pullable lever?

title.children: Everybody goes bananas, then nothing happens: The flawed truth about the latest negative gearing outrage

image.altText: Voters must now number every square on the ballot paper.

props.synopsis: From news, analysis and explainers through to election previews, key electorates and candidates, Queensland Votes has the latest on the upcoming state election. Click through to read more.

title.children: Queensland Votes 2024 — stay up to date with the latest election news and analysis

image.altText: Streaks of light are seen against a darkening sky with light clouds above a city

props.synopsis: Iran has fired about 200 missiles at Israel in response to the killings of senior leaders of Hamas, Hezbollah and the Iranian Revolutionary Guards. Israel's military says the attack will have consequences. Follow live

title.children: Explosions heard above Israeli cities after Iran fires barrage of missiles

image.altText: People run toward a shelter as a man carries two young children in his arms

props.synopsis: Israel has vowed to retaliate Iran's attacks "at a place and time" of its choosing.

title.children: At least six killed in suspected Tel Aviv terror attack as Iran reports firing 200 missiles at Israel

image.altText: Man in food manufacturing uniform pulling out a tray of pies.

props.synopsis: Adelaide bakery Vili's is about to renew its electricity contract and the cheapest quote will see them paying an extra $100,000 annually. It's forced the business to pass the rising costs on to their customers to stay afloat.

title.children: They're humble Aussie staples, but increasing power costs are forcing their prices up

image.altText: A mobile phone screen shows the report on telecommunication consumer protections.

props.synopsis: Consumers and industry stakeholders are calling for better regulation of phone companies after family members of deceased customers are repeatedly contacted – in some cases for years after a person's death.

title.children: Jenny and other grieving families put through Monty-Python style farce but Telstra won't be penalised

image.altText: A close up shot of a woman with blonde hair mid speech.

props.synopsis: The federal government claims it is "serious" about going to the polls over its unsupported housing bill, which it will reintroduce to parliament, setting up a double dissolution election trigger.

title.children: 'Serious proposition': Government moves to reintroduce failed housing bill, reviving threat of double dissolution election

image.altText: Separate close-up headshots of Tim Walz and JD Vance.

props.synopsis: Do vice-presidential debates influence election outcomes in the United States? They never have in the past. All today’s debate is likely to do — barring any kind of surprise — is reinforce the vibe of each campaign.

title.children: People don't vote the same way they hire CEOs — keep that in mind as you watch today's VP debate

image.altText: Close up of Julian Assange with him holding up a fist.

props.synopsis: Julian Assange is back on European soil. When last here, he was behind bars.

title.children: 'Isolation has taken its toll': Julian Assange in his first public appearance since his release from a UK prison

image.altText: Reporter wears lemon suit standing in front of Brisbane River, with graph representing seats needed to win in election.

props.synopsis: Jessica van Vonderen explains how many seats Labor and the LNP will need to govern in their own right.

title.children: Politics is a numbers game — so how many seats do Labor and the LNP need to win Queensland?

image.altText: Corporate grey office building and ABC logo

props.synopsis: The ABC's managing director apologises after a review finds "systemic" issues of racism have caused hurt to First Nations and culturally linguistic staff.

title.children: 'Hurt, helplessness': ABC review finds racism within broadcaster and staff targeted by external organisations

image.altText: A man with a short tight haircut and military uniform stands speaking.

props.synopsis: In candid remarks during last month's International Land Forces conference in Melbourne, visiting Brigadier General Frank J Lozano expressed confidence that a "coalition of the willing" could outpace Beijing's rising regional dominance.

title.children: Visiting US general warns 'there is a fight coming', as he stresses importance of Australian alliance

image.altText: Sold

props.synopsis: With negative gearing and capital gains tax back on the national agenda, experts say such reforms would be unlikely to lead to a major fall in property prices. But some investors say they could be forced to sell if there are changes to property tax breaks and that could force rents higher.

title.children: 'It's going to be very uncertain for us': Investors weigh in on negative gearing debate

image.altText: Tim Walz smiles on stage.

props.synopsis: Tim Walz and JD Vance haven't spent much time on the national stage – so a lot of Americans don't know too much about them. The debate is one of their best shots to win over voters in an election race that remains tight.

title.children: Vice-presidential candidates Tim Walz and JD Vance are preparing to debate. Here's your guide to the event

image.altText: Aerial shot of a grey SUV driving on an unmarked road through vast field of drown and green grass.

props.synopsis: Some manufacturers said we'd be in self-driving cars by now and that hasn't quite played out. So where do driverless, hydrogen and electric vehicles fit in Australia's driving future?

title.children: Why Australia is so far behind other nations in EV sales, and how utes are part of the problem

image.altText: A woman with an umbrella walks in the University of Sydney quadrangle.

props.synopsis: Anti-Semitism is a "sad indictment" on the Australian university sector, a Senate inquiry has found, but holding a royal commission-like investigation into the issue would be "too slow".

title.children: University responses to anti-Semitism 'woefully inadequate', but Labor-led committee rejects judicial inquiry

image.altText: A person wearing a keffiyeh holds their fingers up in a peace sign, a Palestinian flag is in the background.

props.synopsis: NSW Police has decided to apply to the state's Supreme Court to prohibit two upcoming protests, citing safety concerns for both participants and the community.

title.children: NSW Police to apply to Supreme Court to prohibit Sydney protest on October 7

image.altText: A yellow Hezbollah flag, featuring an arm reaching up to a rifle, seen above a sea of people.

props.synopsis: Federal police are investigating a Melbourne protest where Hezbollah flags were displayed in what shapes as an early test of hate-symbol laws passed earlier this year.

title.children: Appearance of Hezbollah flags at Melbourne rally shape as test of new hate-symbol laws

image.altText: Nicola Gobbo, known as Lawyer X, wearing a leopard print top stares out a window

props.synopsis: Lawyers for barrister-turned-informer Nicola Gobbo say she has lived in a state of fear and constant hiding during the past six years, with details of her secretive life revealed in court during her trial against the State of Victoria.

title.children: Court hears of Nicola Gobbo’s life in hiding, surgery and name change since outing as Lawyer X

image.altText: A Russian military aircraft Su-35 flies next to F-16 jet.

props.synopsis: The US military releases footage showing a Russian aircraft flying dangerously close to a US F-16 fighter jet near Alaska, in a manoeuvre known as "headbutting".

title.children: US military slams Russia for 'headbutting' F-16 fighter jet at close range off Alaska

image.altText: A graphic image showing the NDIS logo, a hand on a calculator, and stacks of folders.

props.synopsis: Significant changes to the National Disability Insurance Scheme start kicking in this week. Here's what you need to know.

title.children: A major NDIS change has just been finalised. Here's what you need to know

image.altText: A plane sits on the runway at an airport. It is white with purple highlights and the word Bonza on the side.

props.synopsis: Investigators are examining why some money destined for a private investment firm's football teams instead went to Bonza. The airline collapsed barely a year after it launched.

title.children: US authorities investigating whether budget airline Bonza was funded with money meant for football teams

image.altText: A blackened burnt-out bus shell is hosed down by several firefighters in full protective gear

props.synopsis: The school bus was taking students on a field trip before it caught fire on a road outside of the Thai capital Bangkok.

title.children: Thai school bus catches fire killing at least 23 people and injuring more than a dozen others

image.altText: a woman with long hair silhouetted against a blue sky with white clouds

props.synopsis: Andy wanted advice for body image and self-esteem issues. Her psychologist suggested she try Chinese acupuncture for breast growth.

title.children: 'Acupuncture for breast growth': Concerning advice from psychologists leaves young people reluctant to seek help

image.altText: Young woman smiling with sky, clouds and Nepal mountain in background

props.synopsis: Legal changes introduced in the wake of the September 11 attacks, which only took effect in 2022, mean that unless there are exceptional circumstances Australians are now limited to three name changes in a lifetime.

title.children: Anti-terrorism law change traps woman with 'hippie whim' name she doesn't use or want
